instruction: Make a list of desirable Skills for software engineers to add to LinkedIn.
output:
A software engineer is a person who applies the principles of software engineering to the design, development, maintenance, testing, and evaluation of computer software. They are responsible for the development and maintenance of software systems, writing code, and debugging programs. Software engineers also have knowledge of algorithms and data structures, and they can apply these to solve complex problems.
To be an effective software engineer, you should possess strong problem-solving skills, good communication skills, and the ability to work well in a team environment. You should also have a strong understanding of computer science concepts, such as object-oriented programming and algorithm design. Additionally, knowledge of scripting languages, such as Python or Java, is important for building software applications.

instruction: Discuss the origins and history of the word that has been given to you.
input: oblique
output:
stroke (plural oblique strokes)
(typography) A character with an oblique stroke is one whose horizontal and vertical strokes are not perpendicular to each other.
A cursive letter has oblique strokes.
1879, James T. Shotwell, The Penman's Guide to Ornamental Lettering: :In the formation of the letters of the Roman alphabet, there is also a very wide range of variation, depending upon whether the strokes are made diagonally or horizontally, oblique or straight. ,
1967 April 9, “The New Photogravure”, in The Times (London, England), Sunday edition, page 15:
The forms that he evolved for his typefaces were variations on traditional roman types, using many diagonal elements (oblique strokes) and contrasting thick and thin lines.
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=oblique_stroke&oldid=46980230"

instruction: Write a step-by-step guide for resolving GitHub merge conflicts.
output:
Update: This post is now out of date. Please see GitHub's documentation on resolving merge conflicts instead.
I struggled a lot with merge conflicts in GitHub, and finally I found the best way to resolve them. These are not in any particular order.
You have two branches. One is your local branch (let's say, "develop") and another is a remote branch ("remotes/origin/develop"). Open these two branches in your editor or IDE. Now make sure both are identical. For example, if your local branch is at line 400 and remote branch is at line 399, add one more line in your local branch and push it to the remote branch.
This command will create a new local branch called "merged" which should be identical to both "remotes/origin/develop" and "your-local-branch". In my case, my local branch was "develop" so command would be:
$ git checkout -b merged remotes/origin/develop develop
Now you can commit and push your changes to the "merged" local branch.
If your local branch is already up-to-date with the remote branch (i.e., you didn't make any changes locally), you don't have to do anything. Just type:
$ git checkout merged
and you are done. You can now merge your local branch into the remote branch.
Your local branch is now ready to be merged into the remote branch.
Let's assume you want to merge "develop" into "master". Switch to "develop" branch and run the following commands.
$ git checkout master
$ git merge develop
In GitHub, when you try to merge a branch, it gives you two options - edit the diff and then merge or skip the editing and merge anyway. If you have a lot of conflicts, choose the first option and solve all the conflicts. Once you

instruction: You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.
input:
Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.

input: Dead Poets Society

instruction: Name the top cities in France that should not be missed. Include the best aspects of each place as well.
output:
The top cities in France that should not be missed are:
1. Paris - The city of love, romance and fashion. It's famous for the Eiffel Tower, Louvre Museum, Arc de Triomphe, Luxembourg Gardens, and much more. Paris is also a great place to shop, eat out, and experience nightlife.
2. Lyon - The gastronomic capital of France, Lyon is known for its cuisine, wines, and historical landmarks. The old town, called "Vieux Lyon", is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Other attractions include the Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière, the Roman amphitheatre of Fourvière, and the Maison des Canuts.
3. Nice - Located on the French Riviera, Nice is a popular tourist destination for its beaches, Old Town, and annual Nice Carnival. The Promenade des Anglais, a walking and cycling path along the beachfront, is a great place to stroll and people-watch. The Musée Marc Chagall and the Matisse Museum are also worth visiting.
4. Bordeaux - Known for its wine production, Bordeaux is a beautiful city with a rich history. Its center is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and its main attractions include the Cathedral of Bordeaux, the Place de la Bourse, and the Grand Théâtre de Bordeaux.
5. Toulouse - Toulouse is the fourth-largest city in France and is known for its historic architecture, including the Canal du Midi, the Basilica of Saint-Sernin, and the Place du Capitole. The city is also a hub for technology, science, and space exploration, with the European Space Agency having its headquarters there.
6. Marseille - The oldest city

instruction: You will need to guide this person through the scenario they have described for the interview.
input:
Finally! After a while of shooting in the dark and frantically fiddling with sample inputs on the whiteboard, you've came up with an algorithm for solving the coding question your interviewer gave you.
Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.
Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:
"Try to listen to what they're saying...but don't lose your train of thought...ugh, I can't do both!"
output:
Interviewers aren't trying to throw you off. They want to help you succeed. They want to see how you think on your feet, how well you can explain your thought process, and how you can adapt to a new perspective. But they could be making it harder on you by springing curve balls.
So here's what to do when an interviewer throws you a curve ball.
Step 1: Listen and clarify
Hear them out. Keep your body language relaxed and open, show that you are listening. Nod and smile, but don't let those expressions distract from your eyes which should be focused on their face.
Don't be afraid to ask clarifying questions. "Could you please explain what you mean by that?" is a totally acceptable response, especially if you feel like you've lost the thread of what they're saying.
Step 2: Evaluate potential impact
As your interviewer talks, evaluate the potential impact of their suggestion. Is it significant? Could it change the way you approach the problem?
Step 3: Adapt your plan
If their idea will have a big impact, let them know you're hearing them out. "That's a fascinating idea. I hadn't considered it before. Let me see if this adaptation makes sense."
If their idea won't change much, acknowledge it quickly then switch back to your original train of thought. "Yeah, that's true. But I think this is still the best approach."
Step 4: Thank them
Thank your interviewer for their input. "I really appreciate your insight there. It's helped me refine my thinking on the problem."
It helps to thank them even if their idea didn't make a big difference. Interviewers put a lot of work into preparing for coding interviews, and

instruction: You are given a programming problem and its implementation. Analyze the problem and implementation and explain the algorithm and approach used to solve the problem.
input:
Table: Person
| Column Name | Type     |
| personId          | int         |
| lastName         | varchar |
| firstName         | varchar |
personId is the primary key column for this table.
This table contains information about the ID of some persons and their first and last names.
Table: Address
| Column Name | Type     |
| addressId        | int         |
| personId          | int         |
| city                   | varchar|
| state                | varchar |
addressId is the primary key column for this table.
Each row of this table contains information about the city and state of one person with ID = PersonId.
Write an SQL query to report the first name, last name, city, and state of each person in the Person table. If the address of a personId is not present in the Address table, report null instead.
Return the result table in any order.
Implementation:
select FirstName, LastName, City, State
from Person left join Address
on Person.PersonId = Address.PersonId
;
output: This query uses a Cartesian product to produce the output table. In other words, it selects all possible combinations of rows from the Person and Address tables. The ON clause is used to match the PersonId columns in each table. The result set is then filtered to include only the columns being reported.

instruction: The given article should be checked for any scientific errors and corrected if necessary.
input: Zinc is an essential mineral that is required for good health. It is involved in many biochemical processes in the body and is necessary for the proper functioning of the immune system. Excess zink is not harmful as it is excreted in the urine.
output:
However, it is possible to take too little or too much zinc.
Symptoms of zinc deficiency include loss of appetite, poor growth, delayed sexual maturation, and impaired sense of taste and smell. Symptoms of zinc toxicity include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and hair loss. Long-term exposure to high levels of zinc can lead to copper deficiency, which can cause anemia and neurological problems.

instruction: Make the article available in a second language by translating it into it.
input:
Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.
Translate to French:
output: Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.

instruction: An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.
input:
The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music.
output:
The late 19th and early 20th centuries saw a dramatic increase in the popularity of consumer electronics, such as the radio. The radio allowed for increased access to music as it could be broadcast to large numbers of people at once. This led to the development of new styles of music that were tailored for mass appeal. Examples of these types of music include Tin Pan Alley and Hillbilly music.
New media and technologies also emerged during this time that allowed for easier recording, editing, and distribution of music. The phonograph was patented in 1877 and began to be mass-produced by the beginning of the 20th century. It revolutionized the music industry by making it possible to distribute recordings of musical performances on a large scale. In the 1920s, the talking picture or "talkie" replaced silent films and introduced sound recording to cinema. During this period, musicians began to be paid royalties for their work, which had previously been considered an honorarium.
The performance of music became more visual with the advent of television and video recordings. The introduction of rock and roll culture in the 1950s made performing on stage even more important. Some performers such as Elvis Presley and The Beatles became extremely popular, selling out concerts wherever they played.
Music of the 20th century is often characterized by its diversity and experimentation. New styles of music called modern music were created, including atonal music, twelve-tone music, and serialism. Important composers of the 20th century included Arnold Schoenberg, Igor Stravinsky, John Cage, and Karlheinz Stockhausen. Jazz music developed from ragtime and blues to encompass a variety of styles generally characterized by the improvisation of soloists

instruction: Come up with the courses that one is supposed to take in order to be an expert in a given field.
input: Graphic Design
output:
Animation:
1. Bachelor degree in any design field, preferred 2. Skill and knowledge of industry standard software (Adobe Creative Suite) 3. Knowledge and understanding of animation principles and techniques 4. Ability to create visually appealing and engaging animations 5. Excellent problem solving and time management skills 6. Strong communication and interpersonal skills.
7. Portfolio of previous work 8. Familiarity with current graphic design and animation trends 9. Experience working with clients and team members 10. Understanding of color theory, typography, and composition.

instruction: Give students tips on how to keep their nerves under control during class presentations.
output:
Go to a quiet room, take 5 deep breaths, and repeat a positive affirmation.
Make sure you know your topic inside and out, so that you don’t get nervous when it’s time to present.
Practice in front of friends and family to get used to speaking in front of others.
Use visual aids such as PowerPoint or whiteboard to help you stay on track.

instruction: Make a list of the materials that will be required to build the given tool.
input: Coffee Darkness Meter
output:
- A clear container
- A light source
- An opaque container
- A piece of black paper
- A piece of white paper
- A ruler
- A measuring tape
- A thermometer
- A scale
- A stopwatch
Building a coffee darkness meter involves collecting several materials. First, you will need a clear container to hold the coffee and a light source to shine through the coffee. You will then need an opaque container to block the light that is not passing through the coffee. Next, you will need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper to compare the amount of light that passes through each color. Finally, you will need a ruler, measuring tape, thermometer, scale, and stopwatch to measure and track the results.

instruction: Estimate the cost of supplies required to create the given project and calculate the total cost.
input:
DIY Water Chiller
Required items are: Ice-maker, Icebox/cooler, Temperature regulator, Aquarium pump x2, 12V power supply
output:
, Water pump, Tube fittings, Tank for chilled water, Cooling fans.
Instructions: Connect the water pump to the ice-maker and coolant reservoir. Connect the temperature regulator between the water pump and ice-maker. Run the cold water from the ice-maker into the aquarium pump which in turn will run into a tank filled with water at a lower temperature. This water will be pumped back into the ice-maker as coolant. Connect the second aquarium pump to return the water to its original temperature. Finally, connect the temperature regulator between the second pump and the ice-maker to maintain a constant temperature.

instruction: Develop a mental exercise that can help people manage their anxiety and explain how it works.
output: Mindfulness exercises are a great way to help manage anxiety. An example of a mindfulness exercise is to take a few deep breaths, close your eyes and focus on the present moment. As you breathe in, count to 4 and as you breathe out, count to 6. Repeat this cycle for several minutes. This helps to calm the mind and body, reducing feelings of anxiousness.

instruction: Design a medium-level sudoku puzzle.
output:
What is the output of this C++ code?
void printSudoku(int board[9][9]) { int row; for (int i = 0; i < 9; i++) { for (int j = 0; j < 9; j++) { if (board[i][j] != 0) { cout << board[i][j] << " "; } else { cout << "."; } cout << endl; } } }

instruction: Based on the facts that have been provided, prove the following statement.
input:
Statement: "For every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0"
Fact: The square of any real number is non-negative.
output:
Fact: The difference of two real numbers is always less than or equal to their sum.
Therefore, for every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0, since the square of any real number is non-negative and the difference of two real numbers is always less than or equal to their sum.

To evaluate if the Transformer can generalize to other tasks we performed experiments on English constituency parsing. This task presents specific challenges: the output is subject to strong structural constraints and is significantly longer than the input. Furthermore, RNN sequence-to-sequence models have not been able to attain state-of-the-art results in small-data regimes.

instruction: Extract the method that has been used in the research from the abstract of the paper. Give the exact sentences from the abstract that discuss the method.
input: We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse
output: The method used in the research is described in the abstract as "a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning." The key aspect of the method is that it is based on end-to-end deep learning, which allows the system to learn a function that is robust to background noise, reverberation, and speaker variation without needing hand-designed components. The system also does not need a phoneme dictionary or the concept of phonemes. The training system is optimized for performance and uses multiple GPUs, and the data synthesis techniques allow for efficient acquisition of varied training data.

instruction: Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.
input: Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.
output: The code and data are available at https://github.com/fewjoint-team/fewjoint.

Concepts

instruction: Create a list of subtopics for the given topic.
input: Music theory
output:
is the study of the practices and possibilities of music.
Theory may include:

* How music works (harmony, melody, rhythm)
* What makes music pleasing (tonality, consonance, dissonance, counterpoint)
* The relationship between music and mathematics (including tuning and temperament)
* The physical creation of sound (acoustics, psychoacoustics, audio engineering)
* The role of music in culture (music history, musicology)

is a slow-paced psychological horror film directed by Stanley Kubrick, based on the novel of the same name by Stephen King. It follows the story of a family, consisting of father Jack Nicholson, mother Shelley Duvall and son Danny Lloyd, who move into an old hotel in Colorado during the winter season, where they are haunted by supernatural forces and their own personal demons. The movie is renowned for its chilling atmosphere, disturbing imagery and iconic performances from its cast.

instruction: List a few popular songs from the given album.
input: Back To Black
output: is the second and final studio album by British singer Amy Winehouse, released on 20 October 2006 in the United Kingdom and on 3 January 2007 in the United States. It was her first 5 ****** reviewed album, with a score of 91 out of 100 on Metacritic. The album became a huge international success, selling over 10 million copies worldwide, and spawned two number-one singles: "Rehab" and "Back to Black", which won a Grammy Award and an Ivor Novello Award, respectively. Upon its release, Back to Black received rave reviews from music critics, who praised Winehouse's distinctive and soulful contralto vocal style and her songwriting ability, and compared her sound and style to that of legendary artists such as Aretha Franklin, Nina Simone, and Otis Redding.
